p: The EOs of C. squalida, C. sessilifora and My. guianensis showed the most potent antimicrobial activity against Staphylococcus sp. 841 resistant to ampicillin, doxycycline and clindamicyn, isolated from milk samples produced by cows affected by mastitis, with MIC values ranging from 7.80 to 31.25 µg·mL −1. Among these bioactive EOs, emphasis should be given to that from C. squalida, which strongly inhibited this bacterium with the lowest MIC, whose value is considered a good result even for pure substances [ 26]. All tested oils were moderately active (MICs 250 to 500 µg·mL −1) against Staphylococcus sp. 873, also isolated from milk, however showing a larger resistance profile (penicillins, including oxacillin, tetracyclines, lincosamides, quinolones, macrolides and second generation cephalosporines), as well as against the standard strain of S. aureus (MICs 125 to 500 µg·mL −1).
